Dark brown pour with a light tan head.  Aroma has lots of fresh coffee with some roasty malts and chocolate detectable.  Flavor is monsterously coffee-ish with bits of espresso and dark chocolate thrown in.  Really nice coffee stout.

Draft @ GTMW.  Pours a dark brown/black with a thin tan head.  The aroma almost makes this beer perfect (in fact its the first perfect aroma rating I have ever given).  Dead on Creme Brulee.  Huge Vanilla and Caramel notes.  The flavor was great as well.  A bit sweet initially with the caramel and vanilla flavors, but then the coffee and brown sugar come through.  A great dessert beer, or just for regular drinking.

The name of the beer says it all about all features of this brew. Its unbelievable how they nailed down that Brulee aroma. It totally dominates the aroma,taste has apects of vanilla and caramel to give it that very distinct cream flavor, fell apart at the finish and became a little watery, thicken this up a little,bump up that Plato,your king of the coffee ground hill. One of my clearheaded samples at Great Taste

GTMW on tap.  Dark color.  Smell of coffee, malt, caramel and vanillia.  Mostly coffee.  It was like smelling fresh coffee grounds.  Taste is stong roasted coffee, coco, malt, vanilla and caramel.  A little too watery but still a fine stout.

Dark brown to black with a thin tan head, disappearing rapidly.  Big sweet turbinado sugar nose.  Dark  malt.  And though I hate the term, this is definitely screaming sugary girly coffee drink, far more than even the most sugary girly coffee drink ever has.  Creamy subdued mouthfeel, though rather thick, though not too fizzy.  Just right.  Big sweet coffee flavor.  A bit of the coffee acidity makes this a more balanced brew.  At the same time, it does come a bit too close to smelling like an old cold over sweetened cup of joe, but its still very very nice, as I dont view this as a bad thing per se (as long as it isnt actually a cold over sweetened cup of joe).  Creamy, with some diacetyl, though not a bad thing to make this beer even creamier.  Lingering Dunkin Donuts coffee flavor.  Sweet, and very nice indeed.

Wow, coffee coffee coffee.  Tastes like creme brulee, for real.  Aroma is nice, vanilla, sugar, coffee.  The flavor is there, but its weak and watery, unbalanced and rather hollow despite the presence of a nice  coffee/roasty/sugary/vanilla flavor.

I think the best part abou this one is the amazing aroma.  Smells like a coffee shop. Huge coffee cream and sugar.  Taste is much the same, espresso, roasty, some caramel.  Taste gets a little old after awhile, but this brew is definitely worth a try.

If your reading this review, than you might be considering try this beer...Do yourself a favor, and DO IT!

Poured a deep black with little lacing.

THe smell is, well, a mochaccino with cream. Its all those rich coffee textures, some roast, some sweet caramel, some nutty sense.

The taste is heavenly, at least on draft it is. Hits first with black coffee, followed by black with sugar and then slight cream, then comes the toffee, slight hop, and rich mocha.

Superbly balanced, I honestly could swill this all damn night.
Methinks I shall.

The beer is a deep dark brown, and even a gentle pour provides a good two to three inches of fluffy chocolate brown foam. Sweet Belgian chocolate, vanilla, and some coffee in the aroma. Okay head retention, solid webby lacing.

Bursting with flavor - coffee, dark roasted malt, vanilla, bitter chocolate, sweet chocolate, and even some tangy cherry. Dry and tangy in the aftertaste - cherry, coffee, and roasted grain. Body just north of medium, smooth, tasty, and drinkable.

On tap at the brewery.  From tasting notes made at the brewery on 8/22/06.  Pours a dark charcoal black color with a creamy layer of tan head.  Aromas of roasted malt mingle with some cocoa powder, caramel, and milky vanilla.  Medium bodied, sweet mouthfeel.  The vanilla and caramel tones seem to be a bit artificial in the sense that it tastes like its been added to the beer and not a natural creation from the brewing process.  Nonetheless, it tastes good and makes an interesting after-dinner brew.  Finish is a touch watery and contains some nice, dry coffee characters.Additional Notes:  At the time I had this beer on draft, I purchased a 12oz bottle to go.  My intention was to spend some time with the bottled version and combine my tasting notes from the brewpub to make a thorough rate.  Unfortunately, my bottle was infected, so Ive chosen to add my rating based on my draft experience only.  My bottle was a major gusher and total sour bomb, and it looks like most of the other rates from this bottled batch indicate the same problem (Bottled March 2006).  How unfortunate!

Had this on tap at the brewery. Has a sweet coffee aroma with maybe a little artificial vanilla aroma that threw me off a little. Very powerful aroma that lasts forever. Flavor was sweet, no alcohol present, coffee, and vanilla. A lot of flavors that just seemed weird on my palate. Maybe if i wasnt completely hungover this would have been even better.

On draft (nitrogen) at brewery. Pours black with spotty creamy brown head. Big bubbles mixed with tiny creamy ones. Lots of lacing left clinging to the glass. Full truck load of coffee, sweet molasses, caramel and vanilla extract aroma. Rich multi faceted malt flavor. Theres roasted malts, a touch of black patent, chocolate, caramel, some coffee and hints of vanilla here and there. This beer is full flavored leaving a rich roasted malt taste behind. Yet another great beer from Kuhnhenn.

Draft... This beer rocks!... Pitch black ale with a creamy, well-tanned head. Excellent retention. Smells like rich Crème Brûlée; vanilla beans, heavy cream, brown sugar and all. The flavor is a blend of coffee, brown sugar and nuts without cloying sweetness. Lightly acidic. Full-bodied and creamy with soft carbonation. Finishes chocolaty and tangy. Different, world class brew!

On tap at the pub: Black with a big tan head. Some great lacing. Aroma of vanilla, coffee, caramel and chocolate. Flavor, vanilla, coffee, some sweet chocolate as well. Creamy smooth texture, a little thin but overall pretty damn good.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2007 RE-RATE....Tap.   Pours a clear dark brown with a smallish tan colored head.   Aroma is unbelievable, this is the best smelling beer ever, burnt sugar, coffee, caramel, vanilla, oh my!  They should make air-freseners that smell like this.    Flavor is malt, some coffee, burnt sugar, chocolate, vanilla notes.   Palate is somewhat medium light, a little thin, mildly carbonated, mild bitter-sweet finish.   Hands down the most unique aroma of any beer Ive sampled.   I hammered this the first time I rated due to the watery body, but after having it a second and third and forth time, I realize I was a bit harsh, all in all this is pretty darn good.   I musta been in a bad mood!!
Draught at GTM06. Sweet, toffee, buttery aroma. Not much head save a small ring. Totally opaque body. Sweet, beautiful buttery, butterscotch flavor. They nailed the creme brulee.

Bottle, from trade with hopdog. Ok aroma, grape/wine, coffee, a little caramel as it warmed. Im thinking its bad by aroma. Nice dark brownish black color. Big head, filled half the glass, needed multilple pours to empty bottle, nice lacing when faded. Bitter flavor. Tangy, again grape, maybe viney, little coffee or caramel. Medium body, smooth creamy mouthfeel, bitter finish. No creme brulee or java here. Hoping its a bad bottle. Thanks hopdog.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: This draft brew from the Michigan Brewers Guild festival poured a head of frothy dark brown colored bubbles that was mostly lasting and left behind a opaque no visible carbonation black colored body. The very nice aroma was vinous dark malt and mild bourbon. The mouth feel was smooth at the start with a vinous dark malt mild biting finish. The excellent flavor contained notes of roasted malt dark malt and bourbon. Delicious and one I would certainly love ot have again.
Excellent dessert beer.  Sweet coffee aroma with some chocolate.  I tasted several stouts back to back on this day, and this was one of my favorites.

Smal tan head that mostly diminished, no lacing, opaque, no visible carbonation, and a dark brown-black hue. Nose was coffee, brown sugar, chocolate, and caramel. Flavor was coffee, chocolate, sugar, and sweet caramel malt. Mouthfeel was somewhat tingly. Medium body. Nicely done!

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2008 Poured dark black with a thin tan head.  Creme brulee and dark coffee beans dominate the aroma.  Flavor is pretty much more of the same.  Very delicious, but a bit on the one dimensional side and the body is disappointingly thin.

Rerate on 12/30/08:
Far more depth of dark roasted coffee in the flavor and aroma along with a fuller creamy body.

On tap at the Great Taste of the Midwest.  Poured a deep reddish iced tea brown with a short caramel cap.  I very much enjoyed the aroma!... deep dark chocolate, cappuccino, and plenty more dark maltage.  Flavor was right on, too... rich coffee and cappuccino, chocolate, and woodsy hoppage.  Flowed well on the palate, with medium thickness.  Excellent!

On tap at the brewery.  Stunning aroma of an iced cappuccino - amazing.  Very dark brown, creamy off white head.  Taste is like a cold coffee - maybe a bit liked an iced cap, but was a bit of a let down from the aroma.  Tastes way stronger than it is.  A very interesting concoction - a true dessert beer.

Draught. Dark brown, nearing black colour with a mocha cream head and lacing. Smells interestingly breakfast-like with maple syrup, brown sugar, and such. Very unique, to say the least. Roasty to start with maple and coffee substance all around. Sticky in the finish. Becomes a bit monotonous after a while but I think it still has a definite purpose. Cool.

Sampled at the brewpub on July 21, 2006.

Draught at Kuhnhenn. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size lasting creamy tan head. Aroma: Holy shit, that smells friggin amazing! Like an iced coffee mochachino or something. Coffee, chocolate, burnt sugar, caramel and more -- wow, I just couldnt stop smelling it. The flavour doesnt quite live up to that aroma but it does not dissapoint: lots of coffee with chocolate, sweet caramel malt and burnt sugar -- quite tasty. Medium bodied. What an interesting and unique Stout, I thought it was fantastic!

Draught sample at the brewpub. Deep brown-black with a small tan head. Aroma - OH MY FUCK! Coffee, caramel, chocolate, burnt sugar - huge and amazing! Flavour isnt quite so mind blowing, but still very nice, like an iced mocha. I suppose the sweetness might get to be a bit much in a larger sample, but I certainly had to problem getting this one down. Too bad the bottles have been prone to infection, Id love to get my hands on some for home consumption.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2006 Draught.  At the brewpub with blankboy, GregClow, jerc and tupalev.  I had a bottle of this once, but it was infected so I couldnt rate it - glad to get another shot!  Poured opaque black with a decent creamy tan head.  Aroma - good god thats nice - burnt sugar, thick sweet coffee, chocolate, molasses, even some light hops - awesom, Greg called it:  "like an iced cappuccino."  Taste was surprisingly bitter - espresso grounds, bakers chocolate, but thick and creamy too, sweetened table cream, molasses, a bit of alcohol, or vanilla extract - some bitterr hops in the finish.  This is thick, syrupy, bitter and sweet, chewy - lovely mouthfeel, an awesome, yummy stout, but a tad overwhelming after a while - a pint of this would finish me.

Draft @ Kuhnhenn. Dlack body with a dark tan head. Holy schnikes that is quite the aroma! Vanilla extract, mild notes of maple syrup, and a good base of sweet caramel. A bit of coffee in the aroma that I dont care for only comes to my attention after taking a sip. Probably a 10 aroma otherwise. Sweet malt with brief glimpses of the featured aromas before they are swamped by dilute watery coffee. Medium palate is fairly smooth (3+). I should have just smelled it and finished happier! Sigh.

At the last (final) Heavyweight Open House:  Yummy aroma - thick with rasberries and perfectly bitter chocolate.  This is a very interesting sweet stout - its very tart, yet very well-balanced and surprisingly refreshing.  Good.

Huge thanks go out to the person that brought this to the HW Open House - probably the most unique "stout" Ive had since New Glarus Cherry Stout - the aroma is all creme brulee and chocolate - it smells like a dessert at a fine restaurant - the flavor, however, is nothing like that - it is actually quite tart, almost acidic - it takes some getting used to, but once you embrace the dichotomy it becomes a rather enjoyable experience - creamy vanilla and cocoa sit way in the back while the sour, drier qualities tickly your tongue - in short, me likie.

Dark brown with a foamy brown head.  Aroma was burnt nuts, chocolate and some espresso.  Flavour was full and rich with lots of coffee and some roasted malts.  A sugary taste enters at the front but the finish is quite sour and acidic.  Starts great but I just wasnt into the acidic bitterness at the finish.  I think if it were creamier like creme brulee I would have loved it.
Bottle 341ml. Appearance: dark brown with a brown head. Aroma: chocolate, rosted malt, sour acid. Flavor: sour, chocolate, coffee. Conclusion: infected same like GonZoBeer. Thank Ian.

On tap at Kuhnhenns.  Dark beer with a reddish glow at the dimple of the snifter.  Brown foam head.  Delicious nose like coffee ice cream.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Flavors of sweetened coffee, vanilla and dark caramel.  Nice long coffee bean bitterness in the finish.  I really enjoyed this treat.

Aroma:chocolate,rosted malt,sour acid aroma.....
Appearance:hazy dark redish-brown,light brown head...
Flavor:mixe of sour and chocolate,infected.....

UPDATED: APR 6, 2006 Bottle, black with espresso-like head; unfortunately cannot put a word on the dominant smell but coffee comes in as the second one; sourness is the dominant flavour followed by coffee and then by some bitterness. Overall, found that the beer was somewhat off, not balanced.
Deep dark stout with no head. Torrefied coffee with vanilla notes in aroma. In mouth, just burned coffee, with no hops, no sweetness. Rather thin in mouth. Mondiale 2005.

dark black pour w/ hints of purple in it and a tiny whispy tan head w/ some lacing.  Smells of coffee vanilla some burnt sugar notes and cherries.  Maybe this was a bad bottle but the palate was thin and flavor was super sour cherries w/ some hint of creme brulee.. Not very good.. I think this bottle may have been spoiled.

Draft at brewpub. Poured a black color with an average light brown head that diminished slowly and produced good lacing. Heavy vanilla and caramel coffee aroma. Medium to full body with a sticky creamy texture. Full sweet roasted malt flavor with a moderate finish.  Good brew.

Pours deep red brown/black with a neat little brown head. Nose of coffee, vanilla, and tobacco. Other aromas are more easilly detectable after the first sip, including chocolate and cherries, and notes of burnt sugar, which are incorporated into the flavours.  Very tart with cherries, and pepper. Lots of citrus and chocolate. The body is far thinner than the richness of the nose would suggest. The aroma is exceptional and helps bump up the ratings a bit. A little chalky in the finish.

Bottle, dark brown in color, nice brownish head with med. lacing, great aroma of coffee, chocolate, makes you want to down the whole thing, the taste lets you down, get a sweet chocolate and coffee taste but then the tart sets in and makes you think you just drank a lambic, was also too thin, was interesting but I didnt like it.

Much thanks to hopdog for sharing this bottle!
Appears a brownish black with a thick tan head that fades quickly.  Spottly lacing is left all over the glass.
The smell is of caramel, cream, vanilla, and chocolate...heavenly
Taste was a dropoff comparing to the awesome aromas.  Lacto sourness with some caramel cream coming through.
Mouthfeel is of sour and sweetness with a coffee bitterness punching around.
Drinkability...the aroma alone is worth cracking one open but dont get the taste buds overly excited.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with Styles (thanks!). Bottle labeled best before 8/4/05 & bottled on 4/4/05. Poured a dark black with brown edges and an averaged sized brown head. Aromas of lactose, chocolate, coffee, and light vanilla. I was really into this aroma and it reminded me of a coffee latte. Tastes of light sour milk (is that because this bottle is a couple months past date), bitter coffee, and caramel. Tastes a little bit of a let down compare to the awesome aroma.

I can tell this is gonna be a lively on...After cracking the cap the beer fizzed up and out.  Now to taste the remaining 2/3.  Pours pitch black with a fizzy brown head.  The aroma is sweet hazelnut coffee.   I may have gotten a bad bottle.  This beer is really sour.  After a second sip, I decided that this is a definate drain pour.  All around foul!  Id really like to re-rate from a separate batch sometime.

Sampled at the World Beer festival. I dont generally like the idea of trying to rate at a beer fest but I had 6 samples of this one. Dark brown in color with tan head. Delicious aroma with brown sugar, coffee, and some chocolate. Spectacular flavor has creamy vanilla and chocolate notes to go with the coffee and a sweet sugary finish. Delicious beer.

Had to try this, was holding it for a while, and I have seen the ratings go down from bad bottles and unpleasant sourness. Well, got a good Fizzst from the cap removal. Damn, almost no head, from an aggressive pour?? Nose is coffee man.  Taste is sour and dry. Taste like coffee cola, A shame really. Heard so much about this, but, I apparently have a bad bottle, as this is not the best coffee, stout, brew. Not even close. Oh, I dont want to waste this, but is this a sour beer? whew!

Black, well carbonated pour with a quickly diminishing tan head. The aroma is mix of sweet chocolate and coffee.  The flavor is very intense.  Tangy.  Chocolate, coffee and fruit?  Reading the bottle I didnt expect a heavy raspbeery flavor but there it is.  A very different sort of stout.  Smooth creamy palate.  I just cant get over this flavor.  Im not sure if I like it, but it is new and different and that is worth some praise.

(Bottle, courtesy of Pailhead)  Pours a opaque black body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of candish cream, chocolate, and roastiness.  Flavor is sweet and somewhat taer with mild roasted malt and coffee finish.  Interesting...

The carbonation was hiding in the flat, headless black ale. 
Once brought to the lips a redemption that climbs as the flavors of coffee and crème brule (really) evolve into a pleasant bitter. 
Black, almost flat- very flavorful and good.

Sampled at the Great Taste of the Midwest, Madison, 8/13/2005. This was my second beer of the day following their Old Ale.  Im surprised to see this one scored as low as it is, but in looking at the previous reviews, apparently some have complained of sourness. There was none present in my sample. The nose on this one is is exceptional: burnt sugar and toffee with a roasted coffee richness. My wife smelled this and said, "I bet Ill like this one." The flavor wasnt much to her liking, but I was impressed. Meeting the previously mentioned flavors were dried prune and raisin with more mocha cream. Its central weakness was its thinness.
Pours brown with a light brown generous head.  Smells of roasted coffee beans.  Tastes very tarte with some strong cherry elements.  Not at all what I was expecting.  Nice crabapple finish.

On tap at GTMW.  Aroma of creamy coffee, vanilla and chocolate.  Very similar to crem brulee, as I had some just a few days ago.  Dark black with a thin brown head.  The flavor has an initial coffee flavor with a sharp, sour, creamy twist.  Great chocolate-sweet finish.  I like the sourness in this one.  Soft carbination, medium body.  I dont get what people are saying about the sourness.  Sure it was sour, but not that bad...the other creamy, vanilla, chocolaty flavors complimented the sourness.  Try some fresh sometime.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2008 On tap at GTMW 2007.  This one smells absolutely amazing.  EXACTLY like Crème Brûlée.  WOW!  The beer has a dark black body with a tan head and good lacing.  The flavor was not sour like other people are bitching about.  I got coffee and Crème Brûlée.  The palate is a touch light. 10, 4, 8, 3, 17 = 4.2

Cask at GTMW 2008.  HOLY HELL!  Much better!  I drank an absurd amount.

Thanks to Secret Santa for this beer.

Poured black with a small creamy brown head.  Aroma is AMAZING... it smells exactly like a Creme Brule!  I just want to sit here and absorb the aroma... simply incredible.  Tasting... aw !#$!$!#$#!.  Sour.  Cant taste anything but sourness.  What the !#$!#$!#.  I dont know if Im going to cry or break something.  What the hell happened?  Obviously infected, but why does it still smell so good?  Seems like Santas elves took turns pissing in this, but I guess elf urine smells like sweet desserts.  I was really looking forward to this, and now Im just completely irritated.  This sucks on so many levels.  My first Kuhnhenn brew, wasted.

12oz bottle. Dark black color. Small sized tan colored head. Aroma is chocolate fudge, vanilla, coffee, cinnamon, cookies etc. This is one of the best smelling beers I have ever experienced.  Sean and I both said (Best aroma ever about the same time..)Then I had to spoil the effect by drinking it. Sour, lactic and thin. Is the wonderful overall sweetness of the aroma part of the sour lactic taste? I mean how can a beer smell so good and taste like something that could gag a maggot? This is the first beer to get a 10 on aroma and a 1 in flavor. I am sooooo confused. Mouthfeel is thin and watery. Finish is crisp and harsh. Aftertaste is sour and then even more sour. Overall I liked this beer and definitely want to try it fresh. BUT pour it in a big shifter swirl it around and sniff it all night. Under no circumstances drink it!

Bottle courtesy of Styles.  Best by 8-4-2005 - so it looks like Im still in good standing.  Pours a medium viscosity, mostly opaque and midnight brown in color.   Dancing bubbles for the head and a fizzy looking body.  Aroma draws out caramel cappuccino, tiramisu, coffee grinds, brown sugar, blackened oats and dark chocolate.  Flavor leads me to believe that Kuhnhenn might have been a little bit generous with their "best by" date.  Medium-bodied, slick and searing from potentially oxidized qualities.  Some elements of cocoa powder, syrupy espresso, bitterness and a zingy caramel sugariness.  Crème Brûlée characteristics manifest most in the finish.  A bit of a lackluster, but happy for the experience.

On tap at the brewery, into a mug.  Its going to pain me to have the highest rating for this beer, as I pride myself on being a bit of a hard ass, but I cant betray my impressions for the sake of conformity.  Ive had this beer twice, once from the tap and once from a leaky growler.  The opened growler version was sour as all hell and horrible.  I can only assume that those of you who panned this beer had unsealed samples that oxidized or something.  Fresh this was awesome; it lived up to the smell you all rave about.  Thick creamy tan to light brown head over opaque black.  Medium thickness lacing is sticky, eventually crumbling lke a bunch of ice floes.  Caramel mocha smell with chocolate liquour, like Kalhua, all dopeness in the wafting esters.  Sweet and medium-full mocha up front, dry coffee ground and bakers chocolate finish.  Great transition between the dessert sweetness and the dry, powdery finish.  Silky smooth texture, not as full as other stouts but I wouldnt say watery either.  Where do I complain about this beer?  I cant.  If only I could be confident in the bottles, I would seek this out in trades.  As it is, I might just wait until Kuhnhenn starts distributing kegs.  Please try a fresh sample, all you disappointed consumers; its worth the effort.

12 oz. bottle.  the powerful aroma of coffee & creme hits you hard!  this black beer had some but not a lot of head or lace and seemed rather thin upon the pour.  flavors of coffee, vanilla and some bittersweet chocolate up front, but WHOA.... who dropped the bag of Sweet Tarts in my beer?  the finish is sour indeed.  an interesting brew, worth a try for any stout lover, but not one I would come back to anytime soon.  Thanks to Pailhead for sending this one my way!

What the hell... i mean seriously now, What the hell? No wait... youre not understanding what Im saying.. i mean really absolutely, no kidding.. WHAT THE HELL has happened here. Pop the top and you get a black colored stout with a very thin disappating tanned head and moderate levels of lacing. The aroma is explosive and absolutely stunning. THIS IS THE BEST AROMA I HAVE EVER SMELLED HANDS DOWN...from beer or food alike. The euphoric mix of vanilla, chocolate, coffee, mocha, cinnamon sticks, brownies, cookies, bread, milk, raisins was phenomenal. This beer could be smelled for hours on end without question. BEST..... AROMA....... EVER (comic book guy on the Simpsons)! Then I made the biggest mistake of my life... I tasted it! Save me...as Ernest said, want to die now!!! Absolutely ram me up the ass three ways from Sunday sour with an abrasive aceticness. Where in the hell did that nasty carbonation and lactic foulness come from. My first impression is without a doubt that this batch was infected, but why would Kuhnhenn distributed an infected batch..that makes no sense... IT MAKES NO SENSE!!!! And if Chubaka makes no sense...you must acquit! Its as if theyve taken a stout and cross-bred it with a flemish sour ale. I dont think ive experienced a larger 180 in a beer before...ever! Somewhat sticky beer, sour horrid finish. Cmon guys weve sent people to the moon with less planning than this... weve got men.... weve got barley... FIX IT!

Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, fully diminishing. Body is black. Aroma is moderately malty (coffee, roasted grain). Flavor is moderately sweet, harshly acidic, lighlty bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, heavily acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation. GAWD!!!  SOUR!!!  KILL ME NOW!!!  SO SOUR!!!  WANT TO DIE!!!
Massive coffee aroma- very latte-esq. Thin brown head, opaque body. Taste is overly acidic, kind of sour. Roasted, burnt flavor. Soy taste. Cloying.

Acidic flavors do take away from what could have been a delectable stout. Nicely coffeed, and even better is the way the sweetness is handless (very raisiny). Good in the flavor department. Great grainy aroma, great dark malt wafts up...A good experience.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: thanks to pailhead for hooking this up,i love coffee stouts.ok,here goes the rating.pours a black body with brown highlights.very little off-white head to speak of.the aroma can only be described as "a cookie bakery".now for the taste.....woah!what the hell happened???starts out VERY sour with a small vanilla finish.im sorry but sourness does not mix well with coffee and cookies.

Deep brown/black color, tannish brown head. Incredible aroma, coffee, toffee, vanilla, chocolate, milk. I smelled this beer for a solid ten minutes before tasting. Flavor was a let down though. Tart cherry, some signs of the coffee but absolutely nothing like the aroma led me to believe. The tartness seemed to have taken away from the body a bit as well. Oh the potential with this beer.

Dense black. Very thin dark tan cap. Super creamed collar remains. Minimal lace in some some spots and skinny sheeting.

Aroma has a good medley of roasted mocha milked coffee with chocolate additions to its roast. A tender amount of dark cherry and purple grapes steep underneath.

Taste is a load of sour milked chocolate. Wow, a doozy of weird souring cream and strangely bitter coffee flavors break the surface up front with tremedous force and brashness. Smoothes off the back end with very light smoothness of chocolate cake and cookie dough. Stays pretty sour and sad for most of its duration. Im wondering if this may be an infected bottle?

Feel is slippery and smooth with a lighter medium body and some empty areas. Not all that active or playful. Just kinda there. Sourness is getting in the way of most of what the feel potentially could be?

Ill need to get another bottle or more to determine the infected theory. Still seemed OK to me in a way but the weird sour tone conjured up a bad vibe on this one.

Thanks to Tim.  Best.Nose.Ever.  Coffee, butterscotch, cream, milk, amazing chocolate.  Deep deep brown body with a dark head.  Flavor is not what the nose says.  Tart cherry and coffee.  I could smell this beer forever.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2010  terrific brewed coffee aroma, and very nice appearance. The rest of the experience is average. There is vanilla, some woodiness, but surprisingly sour. A fresh newly bottled beer, thanks to Tim (IPFreely) for sharing

Black body with an off white head.  Nice looking beer.  WHOA!!!  The intense aroma of foo-foo coffee drink smacks you right away.  Lots of vanilla.  Tastes just like it smells.  I like my coffee black, please.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2005 Thin dense brown head from a vigorous pour.  Frothy on top.  Lots of sludge/sediment in the bottom of the bottle.  Color is black as midnight.  Strong coffee aroma with plenty of roasted grains and a bit of chocolate.  To much coffee for me.  Wow, very strange flavor.  Sour and sweet flavor.  Not sure if this is the way it is supposed to be.  Says that it was bottled in Feb 2005.  Almost tart like a flemmish sour ale.  Very fruity with a combating strong coffee aftertaste.  Not sure what the hell they were thinking with this brew.  Very thin body for a stout.  Finish is bitter from the coffee yet slippery from the sweet, fruity tartness.  A very strange stout and not one that I will likely try again.  Sorry ths is quickly becoming a drain pour.  I dont know.  Maybe the bottle was infected.

[from a bottle at "the Mondial"]
This beer is definitive proof that dark, high gravity beers are overrated on ratebeer.
Almost opaque with no head--dark, reddish brown at thinner parts of the glass.  This beer looked like a glass of coca-cola.  The aroma was of creme brulee and a bit fruity but really lacked character.  Flavour was very dry and subdued and a bit soda watery with a burnt malt finish.  There was a pleasant coffee flavour that developped somewhere near the end of the taste.  Thin body and medium carbonation.  The coffee and malt bitterness lingered.
Mondial de la Bière de Montréal 2005. Arômes de crème, de caramel, de torréfié, de vanille... Tabac même... Saveurs acides de chocolat.

Bottle at Mondial 2005.  Very sweet, chocolatey aroma with mild vanilla hints.  Extremely tempting aroma that is not too off from Dieu du CIels Aphrodisaque.  Mildly transparent dark brown/mahogany color with a small tan head.  Start is somewhat acidic and harsh, but turns chocolatey and sweet in the middle with hints of vanilla.  Moderate roastiness to finish.  The acidity and lack of body really detracts from this beers marvellous aroma.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2006 Rerate 8/8/06: I got this bottle out of the cooler at Kuhnhenn, so I can attest to its handling.  Pour fills the glass with about 80% foam.  After it all settles, the aroma is full of tart fruity notes with some mild roastiness.  Body starts lightly sweet and caramely malty, quickly turning sour toward a dry, woody, ashy, and smoky tart finish with lingering mocha notes.  Somethings definitely infected here, and this is the second time Ive noticed it.  Maybe, the error lies in the way they (hopefully) sterilize the coffee that gets added, because Ive never noticed infections in any of their other beers.

Original rating 5/25/05: Dark and opaque with a thin, tan head with marginal lacing.  Has a nice roasty coffee aroma reminiscent of Founders Breakfast Stout with some sweet caramel and chocolate malts, and a touch of light fruity tartness.  Starts lightly malty and sweet but unveils some sour, acidic character that I find out of place.  Finshes semi-dry, lightly tart and the roasty coffee shows up again amidst dark chocolate.  Get rid of the acidity and add a touch more malt and you got a great beer.  Thanks to jtw for the bottle!

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2006 Not the nitro version. I was drinking with pintbypint and he had accidentally ordered the nitro version. The body is black with amber highlights and traces of a head on top. The aroma is strong coffee sweetened with brandy and maple syrup. The taste is light coffee with grass and dark chocolate. As you drink, you also get molasses hints. Had this again at a festival. Still a solid beer.

On tap, nitro. Poured near black, red highlights. One inch of sticky dark tan foam. Nice lacing. Light mouthfeel. Creamy chocolate notes in the flavour, also faint vanilla. Aftertaste of bitter chocolate.

Bottle from Walleye: Pours nearly opaque with crimson highlights and a fading frothy head which leaves a ring and good lace. The aroma is pure chocolate and vanilla latte with a hint of berry and earthy esters. The taste is less refined with the expected coffee, mocha, and vanilla bean notes but also displayed some interesting sour fruit and charred wood notes. A finish of some lingering bitters and grainy notes. The feel is a letdown, fizzy and thinner than I would have guessed. Different from most Java Stouts as the vanilla bean and mocha character is more dominate and then there is that lactic/fruity sourness than keeps you wondering. A darn solid brew but something I can say is probably not for everyone.

Smells great! Looks great! Tastes like... a lager and a bitter cup of coffee simply poured together. Not too appetizing, this one. I feel like theyre trying to cover up the unbalance of flavors by adding very sweet, almost fruity flavors.

Pours a deep black color with a very small brown highlight and a thin light brown head. Wow, amazing aroma of coffee, roasted malt and chocolate, maybe vanilla too. The flavor is very different, its much more lactic with coffee, chocolate and roasted malt notes. Medium body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. This beer feels a bit like a let down since the aroma is so excellent and the flavor while being good is less amazing, still this is an enjoyable stout. Merci Stephen !

Bottle: Coffee brown, nearly black, foamy beige head, thin, smeared lacing.   Freshly ground coffee bean dominates.   Subtle roasted malts.   Lactic up front, slightly sour immediately after.   Trailing lambic like sourness.   Light bodied Stout, mouthfeel much the same.   Confused finish, heavily roasted malt based lambic, or baby gueuze.   Great nose, but didnt follow through.   Quite interesting otherwise.   Thanks John!

Black with maple hues. Thick beige ring of foam retains well. Spent coffee beans aroma with chalky accents. Phenolic, toffee pudding, and lactose whispers. Notably airy and fuzzy. Light bodied. Heavy acidity stymies the fullness with a frontal assault of yogurt and soured plums. Smoky phenols lurk  in the background. Lengthy java finish shows hints of cinnamon, roasty malt, and more custard flavors as the body possesses just enough softness to curtail the acridness. The full-blown acidity is puzzling, especially with this being a relatively young bottle. Otherwise, behind the overt coffee presence in the aroma, theres a good degree a brightness. A noble effort.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Strong cocoa and roasted malt, coffee-like aroma.  Opaque brown-black with decent but short-lived, off-white head that recedes rapidly to ring.  Chocolate, pit fruit and roasted malts with a mild cabbagey note in the flavour that is not wholly unappealing.  Medium body with moderate carbonation that feels a bit strong.  Tulip glass, just above fridge temp.  Enjoyed with ClarkVV, MartinT, muzzlehatch and Rastacouere.

New England Road Trip Easter 05 with MartinT, tiggmtl and Rastacouere, beer #36. Sampled in our motel room, joined by the locquacious and sagacious ClarkVV.  12 oz bottle.  Solid black, tiny head falls into a miniscule ring...absolutely jawdropping chocolate-latte aroma, burnt caramel rustling with bourbon vanilla and the tiniest hint of black cherry...sweetened Turkish coffee in the body, bit of wine...somewhat thin and too-carbonated late, so it doesnt quite ascend the mountain, but damn if I cant still smell it.

Thanks again Clark! This Kuhnhenn stout sure does resemble the acclaimed Founders Breakfast stout. It is very dark brown and proposes a nice off-white ring. Its aroma is an overwhelming espresso medley, not even beany, this wins big points considering the vanilla undertones. I rarely encounter them without this usually unpleasant beany aspect. Strong chocolate complexities make this a total dessert brew. Strongly carbonated body, medium in size. It has pleasant sweet and tart vanilla essence notes that match the chocolate in an overall sweet flavour profile that doesnt quite match the aroma, but this remains a surprisingly good stout.

Scrumptious coffee beans and cream flourish within the dark chocolate...Mild coffee bean and malt roastiness blend well and fade into a sweet, quiet finish...Decadent simplicity remains simply decadent...Thanks Clark for this bottle!!...

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2006 draft and bottled versions are nearly identical.  intense coffee aroma, but augmented by a strong sweet caramel aroma--an interesting contrast.  quite silky smooth, essentially no element of alcohol.  unfortunately, later batches of this have been plagued by infections.  ive decided to average the scores based on the decent taste of fresh stuff and the acidic artificial taste of the bad stuff since i probably had more samples of bad bottles.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2006 Draft at Kuhnhenn. Pours an oily black color with basically no head. Nose is sweet sugary malt with tons of fresh ground coffee. Taste is vanilla ice cream dunked in a latte. Very sweet but not overly powering, there is still lots of coffee and lots of roasty flavors. Vanilla seaps through the edges to give a tinge and it finishes with a filmy palate.

This stuff is more like a shot of beer in a mug of coffee rather than the other way around.  But damn it works.  Plenty of java in the aroma.  Nice deserty flavors of chocolate and roasted malts.  
This stuff is the best breakfast beer in Motown.

Pitch black, tan creamy head.  The aroma was awesome if you dig desert.  Loads of vanilla crème brule, cold espresso grounds, and a nice hint of milk chocolate.  Tasted like liquid vanilla custard, coffee, and chocolate. A light hop bitterness at the end kept it only steps away from hitting the cloying line.  Light to medium bodied, soft carbonation, caramelized vanilla custard like finish.  Good stuff, but you probably dont want to make this your session stout....

On nitro at the release party.  Dark brown, almost black with a foamy tan head and great lacing.  Lots of carmel and coffee in the aroma.  Coffee, chocolate, and hints of carmel in the taste.  A bit thinner than I would have expected, but that makes it a bit easier to drink. Overall, a very tasty, easy to drink brew.

First, let me say that I had HUGE expectations for this beer.  Im a big fan of Kuhnhenn brews 99% of the time, HOWEVER - This one just didnt do it for me.  The stout was almost black with a darker tan head.  The aroma was reminiscent of flavored caramel coffee to me.  The tast however, was nothing like the strong "in your face" nose.  The beer struck me as sweet at first, then watery and thin - followed by bitter coffee.  I was a bit disappointed, but hey - beer can be fickle...

Almost totally black with a creamy tan head. Roasted espresso aroma which is just heaven. Taste is thinner in body than expected but tasty none the less. Nice vanilla flavors compliment the rich coffee & chocolate taste.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 On tap:  The aroma contains lots of expresso, chocolate, and cream.  Its a dark brown with no transparency and a small tan head.  The flavor starts with lots of chocolate and some roasted malt.  Theres lots of expresso in the finish with light vanilla and cream.  The flavor reminds me of a dark chocolate and coffee truffle,

Nitro tap.  Deep black in color with a creamy light brown head. Excellent lacing.  Big coffee aroma pretty much dominates the nose, not a lot of malt sneaks out.  Sweet and sugary flavors, having never had Creme Brule I am going to guess that this is what it tastes like.  A bit sour towards the end.  Body is watery which is disappointing.

from the tap at the brewery.pored black brown a nice size tan head. aroma hazelnut caramel,dark cherries, Irish cream. flavor same as above. wow this is a greak java even though this is differant than bells java it is far better I just hope they keep brewing this.

2004 Great Taste of the Midwest. Dark brown body, no real head. Very big and sweet aroma that reminds me of coffee filled with irish creme... consists mostly of sugary coffee and vanilla. Dry watery taste with some vanilla and slight vinous notes, and of course some sweet coffee. A very light, but interesting stout.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2005 05 Great Taste:  Black body, tan head.  SUPERB creamy, chocolatey aroma!  Coffee and choclate mousse all the way.  Slightly lacking flavor and mouthfeel.  Balanced between black malt and leafy hops.  Black malt tart finish.

04 Great Taste.  Black body.  Dry fake chocolate frosting aroma with fig notes.  Big sugary, vanilla flavor with a coffee finish.   I wish I could have spent some more time with this one - seems really interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2006 2004 draught at MI summer beer fest.  Pours a dark beige/hazelnut brown with some darker black waves in it.  Small light brown head and plenty of rich oily coffee aroma.  Aroma gets in your face, like a cold cup of coffee poured from the end of the pot.  Very roasty, oily and nutty.  Flavor is much the same.  It tastes like an iced latte with a couple shots of espresso and a hint of vanilla syrup.  The flavor is wonderful, but the body is very loose and gets a tad watery on the finish.  There is some sweetness towards the finish, but it tastes lightly syrupy (but not cloying).  Strange beer here, but it is a great drink for breakfast.  Body is medium, low carbonation, slightly watery.2005 bottle  Wow, dont remember the aroma being this intense.  Extreme cappucino/mocha notes invade the nose.  Head is well-retained and the body is heavily sedimented (unfiltered).  The body could use a good deal more maltiness, and there are some dry, almost cardboardy notes, that get in the way of enjoying this as much as I would like to.  Brown sugar, honey and coffee beans round out the finish.  Medium body could be a bit fuller.
